Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I was sitting in the break room at the pharmacy, skimming through the latest newsletter about new drug releases, trying to keep up with the ever-changing world of medications. My phone buzzed—my son’s school was calling. My heart sank as the principal explained that my child had been caught stealing snacks at the corner store. As a parent, I knew I had to teach him about honesty and consequences, to guide him toward the right path. But as a pharmacist, I was already behind on my professional reading, and the pressure to stay updated was mounting. I felt torn—my child needed me to be present, to talk, to discipline with love and understanding. Yet, my career demanded constant vigilance and learning. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each expecting my full attention, each unwilling to wait. I stared at the unread newsletter, my mind racing with what I would say to my son, feeling the tug-of-war inside me grow stronger with every passing second.
